channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Birds kept dropping dead in D.C. A biologist cracked the case.
item.description: A call led to a weeks-long investigation and a new discovery in the District.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: For 30 years, I’ve been ‘nice’ to my in-laws. I’m tired.
item.description: Ask Sahaj: For 30 years, I’ve been ‘nice’ to my in-laws. I’m tired.

item.title: White House and IRS officials clashed over sharing immigrants’ tax data before the agency head was ousted, people familiar say
item.description: The tax agency said Friday it wouldn’t tell immigration authorities whether people had claimed the earned income tax credit, citing privacy protections, the people told The Washington Post. Later that day, Billy Long — a former Republican member of Congress — was on his way out.

item.title: Teen kayakers made the first descent down a sacred river recently freed from its dams. The Post followed their 30-day odyssey.
item.description: The removal of four dams on the Klamath River, which flows from the Cascade Mountains in Oregon to the Pacific coast of California, was a long-sought triumph. The journey down the river would also be a monumental achievement — if the group of Indigenous youth could pull it off.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Zelensky rejects Trump’s suggestion that Ukraine cede territory to Russia as Vance prepares to meet Ukrainian officials
item.description: The U.K. and U.S. are hosting a meeting of European and Ukrainian national security advisers, hours after President Trump confirmed he would meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin next week.

item.title: Trump to meet with Putin in Alaska on Aug. 15, setting stage for Ukraine peace talks
item.description: The president said any deal between Russia and Ukraine would include “some swapping of territories to the betterment of both” countries.

item.title: Texas attorney general files lawsuit to remove fleeing Democrats from office
item.description: Attorney General Ken Paxton (R) filed a lawsuit to remove 13 of the more than 50 Democrats who left the state to block a GOP effort to redraw the congressional map. The move escalates a tense showdown over redistricting ahead of the midterm elections.

item.title: James Lovell dies at 97. He commanded the troubled Apollo 13 spacecraft and was played by Tom Hanks in a Hollywood film.
item.description: In 1970, Lovell shepherded Apollo 13 on its lunar voyage, including a perilous journey back to Earth after an oxygen tank exploded. “Houston, we’ve had a problem,” Lovell told Mission Control as the ordeal transfixed the world. Apollo 13 became a saga of mythological proportions, especially after the film that starred Tom Hanks as Lovell.

item.title: Trump will replace IRS Commissioner Billy Long; Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent will run tax agency in the interim
item.description: Long, a former Republican member of Congress, had little tax policy background. It wasn't clear when a new full-time IRS chief would be named.

item.title: Smithsonian restores Trump to impeachment display in National Museum of American History exhibit but makes slight changes
item.description: The restoration comes after The Washington Post reported that President Donald Trump’s name had been removed from the exhibit’s temporary placard as part of a Smithsonian content review prompted by White House pressure.

item.title: Justice Dept. subpoenas N.Y. Attorney General Letitia James about Trump fraud probe
item.description: One of the subpoenas focused on James’s successful civil fraud case against Donald Trump and his real estate empire, which resulted in a judge ruling in 2024 that Trump and his company needed to pay $450 million in fines, people familiar with the probe said. A second subpoena suggested that the Justice Department is looking into James’s high-profile litigation against the National Rifle Association, which led to court-mandated changes for the group, they said.

item.title: 10 questions, and don't forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Israel’s plan. Tariff impacts. Election fights. Hurricane season. Instagram Map. Weight-loss pills. Female umpire. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Israel’s security cabinet approves plan for military to occupy Gaza City
item.description: The decision comes after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Thursday that his government intends to take military control of the entire Gaza Strip.

item.title: A Senate staffer who survived a stabbing in 2023 could have been the GOP’s voice on crime. His faith intervened.
item.description: Phillip Todd, an aide to Sen. Rand Paul (R-Kentucky), was nearly killed in a random attack in D.C. He took two years to figure out what he wanted to say.

item.title: Judge orders temporary halt to construction at Alligator Alcatraz immigrant detention center in Florida
item.description: The ruling by U.S. District Court Judge Kathleen Williams came after a two-day hearing in a lawsuit filed by environmental groups and joined by the Miccosukee Tribe of Indians.

item.title: Trump will nominate White House economic adviser Stephen Miran to sit on Federal Reserve board through January
item.description: Miran is the chair of the White House Council of Economic Advisers and served in the Treasury Department in Trump's first term. Trump announced the move on social media Thursday.

item.title: The economy is cracking. This trend is most alarming.
item.description: The economy is cracking. This trend is most alarming.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Heartbroken dad wants to approach his daughter about her weight
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Heartbroken dad wants to approach his daughter about her weight

item.title: The trains are not running on time in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: Trump’s tariffs. Tulsi Gabbard. Human rights. Army base shooting. Alzheimer’s clue. Nuclear power. Heathy potatoes. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Trump’s tariffs take effect, potentially upending global trade and prices
item.description: The president has already announced frameworks of trade agreements with roughly a dozen of the country’s closest trading partners, including the United Kingdom, the European Union, Japan and South Korea. But goods from nations with which the U.S. does hundreds of billions of dollars of trade, such as India, Switzerland and South Africa, will see new taxes of up to 39 percent, with India’s rate set to jump to 50 percent in three weeks. Economists say the sweeping new taxes on imports will likely get passed on to U.S. consumers and businesses.

item.title: Trump warns companies they will pay double for computer chips unless they ‘build in the United States’
item.description: The president’s latest aggressive tariffs policy puts firms under pressure to pledge new investments in the U.S. and could make smartphones and other products more expensive. Apple won an exemption from the new levy after promising to spend an additional $100 billion on U.S. hiring and components.

item.title: Trump administration plans to scale back human rights criticism of El Salvador, Israel and Russia, leaked documents show
item.description: Documents reviewed by The Washington Post show the administration is planning to eliminate or downplay accounts of prisoner abuse, corruption, LGBTQ discrimination and other alleged abuses. The human rights reports were due to Congress earlier this year but have been delayed as the administration ordered extensive changes.

item.title: Research on reversing Alzheimer’s reveals lithium as a potential key
item.description: Scientists at Harvard Medical School have reported that they were able to reverse the disease in mice and restore brain function with small amounts of the compound lithium orotate, enough to mimic the metal’s natural level in the brain. The finding could lead to earlier detection of Alzheimer's, new treatments and a broader understanding of how the human brain ages.

item.title: Trump and Putin plan to meet on Ukraine as early as next week, with a possible Zelensky meeting to follow
item.description: “The Russians expressed their desire to meet with President Trump, and the President is open to meeting with both President Putin and President Zelensky,” White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said in a statement. A meeting could come as soon as next week, according to an administration official.

item.title: Tulsi Gabbard overrode CIA officials’ concerns to release classified report on 2016 Russian election meddling
item.description: CIA officials worried that the release of the House report could reveal top-secret spying techniques and sources, but Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard authorized a lightly redacted version in July, with President Donald Trump’s blessing.

item.title: Five soldiers were shot at Fort Stewart in Georgia, Army says. A suspect is in custody.
item.description: It was not immediately clear whether there were any fatalities. The five victims were taken to a hospital for treatment, officials said. The base was put on lockdown as law enforcement responded to the incident.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: They were ethical vegans till husband flipped for meat
item.description: Carolyn Hax: They were ethical vegans till husband flipped for meat

item.title: Trump raises tariffs on imports from India to 50 percent in bid to stop India from buying Russian oil
item.description: Indian products already faced a 25 percent import tax due to kick in Wednesday night. The new 50 percent rate would take effect in three weeks.

item.title: ‘My teeth told me’: What it was like aboard the Enola Gay
item.description: ‘My teeth told me’: What it was like aboard the Enola Gay

item.title: Leaving this state in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: Federal agencies stepped up arrests in D.C. at Trump’s order. Now Trump threatens takeover of city after DOGE worker was attacked.
item.description: The recent arrests, including many for low-level offenses, were among the latest operations that White House officials say are part of an effort to improve the quality of life in the nation’s capital — a city President Donald Trump has derided as a “dirty, crime-ridden death trap” and pledged to turn around.

item.title: Texas political fight. Epstein files. mRNA vaccines. Palestinian state. Jim Acosta. Titan disaster. Zoo predators. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Texas Republican governor sues to remove Democratic leader amid election map fight
item.description: Gov. Greg Abbott asked the state’s high court Tuesday to remove a top lawmaker from office, arguing he had abandoned his job by leading dozens of his colleagues out of state to block a GOP plan to redraw the state’s congressional map. Legal scholars have questioned whether courts would go along with an attempt to eject the Democrats from office.

item.title: As vouchers soar, their public school shuts its doors: ‘It’s like a death’
item.description: Arizona has supported a robust charter school system, tax money for home schooling and expansive private school vouchers, which are available to all families regardless of income. This “Wild West” of schooling offers a window into the GOP vision for K-12 education.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Cheating college ex has changed a lot in six years. Or has he?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Cheating college ex has changed a lot in six years. Or has he?

item.title: Two artists re-created a 200-year-old garden. This is what they learned.
item.description: We re-created a 200-year-old garden. This is what we learned.

item.title: Republican-led House issues subpoena for Epstein files and summons Clintons, Garland and other high-profile officials
item.description: House Oversight Chairman James Comer (R-Kentucky) issued the subpoena after a subcommittee panel voted to pursue the files. It’s unclear how President Donald Trump’s Justice Department will respond to the request, which includes subpoenas for testimony from officials in both Republican and Democratic administrations, including Bill and Hillary Clinton; former attorney general Merrick Garland and former special counsel Robert S. Mueller III.

item.title: Inside Laura Loomer’s rise in Trump’s orbit: ‘Obsessive’ research, Oval Office visits and ‘contempt’ from staff
item.description: Loomer has taken credit for ousting a raft of federal workers from their jobs, leveraging a personality that friends label “obsessive” and an extreme loyalty to President Donald Trump.

item.title: A ‘wonderful tradition’ in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: One gene reveals clues to why humans thrived and Neanderthals didn’t
item.description: An international team of researchers scrutinized a version of a gene, ubiquitous in humans today, that is not present in Neanderthals or Denisovans — the hominins that lived alongside our ancestors. Their findings suggest tiny changes in brain chemistry could trigger behavioral change that sets us apart from Neanderthals.

item.title: Gaza occupation. Pete Hegseth. Texas map fight. Visa bonds. Disaster funds. Neanderthal genes. Starfish goo. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Top aide to Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth tried to oust a senior White House liaison from the Pentagon
item.description: The unusual dispute received White House intervention and appears rooted in deeper frustrations over failed attempts to fill jobs on the defense secretary’s staff, according to people familiar with the matter.

item.title: Zuckerberg fired the fact-checkers. We tested Meta’s new replacement.
item.description: Our tech columnist drafted 65 community notes, Meta’s crowdsourced replacement to fight falsehoods on Facebook, Instagram and Threads. It failed to make a dent.

item.title: D.C.’s economic picture is getting darker amid federal cuts. These charts show how.
item.description: The Trump administration’s overhaul of the federal workforce is being acutely felt in the region that was already struggling to recover from the pandemic.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Expose friend’s affair or mind your own business?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Expose friend’s affair or mind your own business?

item.title: Israeli government votes to remove its attorney general, a Netanyahu critic who was chief prosecutor in his corruption case
item.description: The dismissal of Attorney General Gali Baharav-Miara is one of the most significant moves in Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s years-long effort to remake the judiciary. It could also trigger a constitutional crisis, pitting the elected government against the power of the courts.

item.title: Ask the sharks in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.
